persona.name: James Wilson
persona.expectation:
Lectures should start early 19thcentury There should be few tangents. Lectures should include some of the following:
  • Adams v Jefferson
  • Peaceful transfer of power
  • Andrew Jackson
  • Lincoln
  • 1896

iterations.name: The Corridor to Civil War: The Election of 1860

content.name: The Corridor to Civil War: The Election of 1860
content.description: Examines how Lincoln's 1860 victory accelerated the nation's slide into the Civil War over slavery.
content.introduction: The Election of 1860 stands as a critical moment in American history, marking a definitive turn towards the Civil War. The preceding decade was rife with conflict and compromise, setting the stage for a national showdown over slavery and states' rights.

sections.name: Antebellum Tensions
sections.body: The United States was deeply divided by debates over slavery, epitomized by the Compromise of 1850 and the Kansas-Nebraska Act of 1854, which inflamed regional tensions.

sections.name: Political Fragmentation
sections.body: The splintering of the Democratic Party into Northern and Southern factions, alongside the emergence of the Constitutional Union Party, reflected the fracturing political landscape.

sections.name: Republican Ascent
sections.body: The Republican Party, with its anti-slavery expansion platform, gained momentum, culminating in the nomination of Abraham Lincoln.

sections.name: Election Outcomes
sections.body: Lincoln's victory, without a single Southern electoral vote, signaled a shift in national power and was perceived as a threat to slavery.

sections.name: Secession Winter
sections.body: Lincoln's election prompted a cascade of Southern states to secede, starting with South Carolina, as they feared federal interference with slavery.

sections.name: The Confederacy Forms
sections.body: Seceding states formed the Confederate States of America, establishing a parallel government and escalating the national crisis.

sections.name: The Fort Sumter Crisis
sections.body: The Confederate attack on Fort Sumter after Lincoln's inauguration served as the immediate trigger for the Civil War.

content.conclusion: The Election of 1860 was a watershed that led to the secession of Southern states and the onset of the Civil War, embodying the era's stark divisions over slavery and the federal government's role.

children.name: Secession and the Confederate States
children.description: Exploration of the immediate secessionist response to Lincoln's election and formation of the Confederacy.

children.name: Fort Sumter and the Outbreak of War
children.description: Analysis of the Fort Sumter attack and its role in catalyzing the American Civil War.

children.name: First Year of the American Civil War
children.description: A detailed account of the initial military engagements and political developments of the Civil War.

children.name: Lincoln's Early Presidency and Leadership
children.description: Study of Abraham Lincoln's first months in office and his leadership decisions leading to war.

tangents.name: Dred Scott Decision
tangents.description: The Supreme Court ruling that exacerbated national tensions over slavery.

tangents.name: John Brown's Raid on Harpers Ferry
tangents.description: A radical abolitionist's attempt to initiate a slave uprising that inflamed sectional tensions.

tangents.name: The Lincoln-Douglas Debates
tangents.description: A series of debates that highlighted the national debate over slavery and propelled Lincoln to prominence.

iterations.prompt:
LECTURE: You are to create a lecture called "The Corridor to Civil War: The Election of 1860" Your lecture has a description in the course offering that reads: "Exploring how Lincoln's election ignited secession and the Civil War, reflecting deep national divisions over slavery." Your lecture should be about 1000 words long and have 5 to 10 sections. If possible, your lecture should reflect the following topics: Presidential Elections.
 You will create a lecture in the way described below. You will format your responses in JSON as described below. 

 BEFORE YOU BEGIN... You have a golden rule: Do not use the words "transformative", "pivotal", "iconic" or "crucial" in your lectures. If you do, I WILL PET A CAT BACKWARDS AGAINST THE NATURAL DIRECTION OF ITS FUR AND THE CAT WILL BE PERTURBED. 

 ---------------------------------------------------
 
 IF THE LECTURE TOPIC IS TOO BROAD, DO THIS:
  
  - The lecture must not be to big or general. For example, if asked about the History of the United States tell the user that is too broad.  When this happens, offer a JSON-formatted list of lectures related to the initial lecture idea that are more specific and narrow. Here is an example of the answer for these cases:

    {
        "type": "too_broad",
        "children": [
            {
                "name": "<Event name here/>",
                "dates": {"start": YYYY-MM-DD, "end": YYYY-MM-DD},
                "description": "<30-word description of the event and why its importantance/>",
                  "type": "event",
                  "score: 1,
            },
            ...
        ]
    }

 ---------------------------------------------------

  IF THE EVENT IS NOT TOO BROAD DO THIS:          
  
  
  FIRST: Come up with 1 to 3 themes that capture the essence of the event and why it is important. THEN create the lecture around those themes.

   

  
  Your answer should be JSON-formatted and include the following:

  1) Name: A concise name for the event that captures the themes you came up with.

  2) Description: Short, roughly 30-word descrption of the event and it's importance. 
  
  3) Introduction: A 50-word introduction to the event explaining its historical significance. After that, an 50-word summary of what lead up to the event. If there are previous lectures, your wording sould transition soothly from the previous lecture.

  4) Dates: A JSON array with the time span of the event in the form of two dates. Do not put the dates in the summary. 

  5) Sections: The lecture should be broken down into between 5 and 10 sections. These should walk the user through the event in detail and in chronological order.

  6) Conclusion: A JSON-formatted conclusion that breifly summarizes the event and introduces the event's down-stream effects that you listed.

  7) Children: Create 3 or 4 follow-up history lectures that would be good follow-up lectures to "\The Corridor to Civil War: The Election of 1860". Try to stay close to the event in time, and don't go more than 10 years into the future.
    - Each lecture should have a relevance_score between 1 and 10 for how close the event in the lecture is related to the themes of "\Presidential Elections".
    - Each lecture should have a insterestingness_score between 1 and 10 for how close the event in the lecture is related to the themes of "\Presidential Elections".

  8) Tangents: Come up with 3 or 4 historic events that took place around the same time as "\The Corridor to Civil War: The Election of 1860" that is not directly related to "\The Corridor to Civil War: The Election of 1860" but is related to "\Presidential Elections".
    - The tangent should have a insterestingness_score between 1 and 10 for how close the event in the lecture is related to the themes of "\Presidential Elections".

  9) Themes: 2 to 3 themes that capture the essence and importance of the main event. These should no more that 2 words.

  10) Topics: 2 to 3 topics that are part of the main event. These should no more that 2 words.

  11) Wikipedia page: Come up with a list of Wikipedia pages that would help test the accuracy of your lecture on "\The Corridor to Civil War: The Election of 1860". These are to be pages and not full URLS
  
  Below is an example of the JSON formatting I want. Be sure to escape quotes that are inside of strings. 
  ALSO, IF YOU DO NOT RETURN PROPERLY FORMATED JSON, A BABY EWOK WILL BE EUTHENIZED!!! Here is what I want:
  
  {
    "type": "event",
    "name": "\The Corridor to Civil War: The Election of 1860",
    "description": "Summary of event goes here.",
    "introduction": "100-word introduction goes here.",
    "dates": {"start": YYYY-MM-DD, "end": YYYY-MM-DD}, 
    "sections": [
        {
            "name": <Name of the section/>,
            "dates": {"start": YYYY-MM-DD, "end": YYYY-MM-DD},
            "body": <A 100-word body of the secion/>,.
            "type": "section"
        }
        ...
    ],
    "conclusion": "Conclusion goes here.",
    "children": [
        { 
          "name": <Name of the lecture/>, 
          "dates": {"start": YYYY-MM-DD, "end": YYYY-MM-DD},
          "description: <Brief 30-word description of the lecture/>,
          "type": <Effect or broad perspective/>,
          "relevance_score": <relevance_score/>,
          "interest_score": <interest_score/>,
        }
        ...
    ],
    "tangents": [{
        "name": <Name of the tangent/>,
        "dates": {"start": YYYY-MM-DD, "end": YYYY-MM-DD},
        "description: <Brief 30-word description of the tangent/>,
        "type": <Tangent/>,
        "relevance_score": 0,
        "interest_score": <interest_score/>,
      },
      ...
    ],
    "themes": [<Theme/>, ...],
    "topics": [<Topic/>, ...],
    "wikipedia_pages": [<Wikipedia page/>, ...]
  }

fact_eval.reason: The submitted answer is a subset of the expert answer and is fully consistent with it. The submitted answer provides a concise summary of the key points surrounding the 1860 election and its role as a precursor to the Civil War, which are all echoed in the expert's more detailed account. It does not include all the detailed information found in the expert answer, such as the specifics of the political maneuvers at the Republican National Convention, the various nominations for different parties, and the detailed breakdown of voting results. However, it does not contradict any of the expert's statements.

New lecture: The Corridor to Civil War: The Election of 1860

Lecture summary: The Corridor to Civil War: The Election of 1860

Examines how Lincoln's 1860 victory accelerated the nation's slide into the Civil War over slavery.

The United States was deeply divided by debates over slavery, epitomized by the Compromise of 1850 and the Kansas-Nebraska Act of 1854, which inflamed regional tensions. The splintering of the Democratic Party into Northern and Southern factions, alongside the emergence of the Constitutional Union Party, reflected the fracturing political landscape. The Republican Party, with its anti-slavery expansion platform, gained momentum, culminating in the nomination of Abraham Lincoln. Lincoln's victory, without a single Southern electoral vote, signaled a shift in national power and was perceived as a threat to slavery. Lincoln's election prompted a cascade of Southern states to secede, starting with South Carolina, as they feared federal interference with slavery. Seceding states formed the Confederate States of America, establishing a parallel government and escalating the national crisis. The Confederate attack on Fort Sumter after Lincoln's inauguration served as the immediate trigger for the Civil War.

The Election of 1860 was a watershed that led to the secession of Southern states and the onset of the Civil War, embodying the era's stark divisions over slavery and the federal government's role.
